Get started

The State Web Template makes it easier to build digital services to meet the needs of Californians.

It offers components and templates to help product teams work more efficiently. Each component and template comes with code to make it easy for you to use them in your project.

If you are new to the California Web State Template please follow instroctions below that will help you started.

If youve downloaded an earlier version of the State Template, you may want to see what's new.

Note: if you are a returning State Web Template user please check Template Updates page for the latest updates notes and updating to the latest version instructions.

Webpage structure

The image below shows the basic structure of a State Template web page, consisting of various elements and building blocks. In our case Nunjucks Includes (njk) are used as our webpage structure main building blocks.

Several common components (such as page headers, footers, navigation, etc.) are included in pages using njk includes.

Code below shows basic State Template web page structure:

HTML Markup

State Web Template structure code: 
 <!doctype html>
 <html lang="en">
    <head>
       <meta charset="utf-8">
       <title>State Template</title>
       <meta name="Author" content="State of California" />
       <meta name="Description" content="State of California" />
       <meta name="Keywords" content="California, government" />
       ❴% include "/src/_includes/head-css-js.njk" %❵
   </head>
   <body>
      <header role="banner" id="header" class="global-header fixed">
        <div id="skip-to-content"><a href="#main-content">Skip to Main Content</a></div>
        ❴% include "/src/_includes/utility-header.njk" %❵/span>
        ❴% include "/src/_includes/settings-bar.njk" %❵
        ❴% include "/src/_includes/site-header.njk" %❵
        ❴% include "/src/_includes/mobile-controls.njk" %❵
        <div class="navigation-search full-width-nav container">
          <div id="head-search" class="search-container search-container featured-search">
          ❴% include "/src/_includes/search.njk" %❵
          </div>
            ❴% include "/src/_includes/navigation.njk" %❵
         </div>
       </header>
       <div id="main-content" class="main-content">
           <div class="container">
               <main class="main-primary">
                  Page content
               </main>
          </div>
      </div>
      ❴% include "/src/_includes/global-footer.njk" %❵
      ❴% include "/src/_includes/scripts.njk" %❵
   </body>
 </html>

Note: Path to the includes will be relative to the directory of your page.

File and folder structure

The following is the file and folder structure for the 2018 State Template package.

StateTemplate/
 â”œâ”€â”€ _site/
 â””â”€â”€ pages/
     â”œâ”€â”€ index.html
     â””â”€â”€ etc...
         â””â”€â”€ sample/
             â”œâ”€â”€ accordions.html
             â”œâ”€â”€ color.html
             â””â”€â”€ etc...
 â””â”€â”€ src/
     â””â”€â”€ _includes/
          â”œâ”€â”€ global-footer.njk
          â”œâ”€â”€ etc...
          â””â”€â”€ layouts/
          â”œâ”€â”€ base.njc
          â””â”€â”€ etc...
          â””â”€â”€ modules/
              â”œâ”€â”€ accordion.html
              â””â”€â”€ etc...
     â””â”€â”€ fonts/
     â””â”€â”€ images/
     â””â”€â”€ js/
     â””â”€â”€ scss/
 â”œâ”€â”€ eleventy.js
 â”œâ”€â”€ package.json
 â””â”€â”€ rollup.config.js
  • _site - This folder contains website's output files.
  • pages - Contains website's input pages that a developer or e content editor can edit.
  • src - The “src” folder contains includes, modules, fonts, images, SCSS and JavaScript files.
  • images - This folder contains all the images used by the State Template.
  • js - Contains JavaScript files that are used by the State Web Template. Third party JavaScript libraries are also included in this folder.
  • _includes - This folder contains the common template components used on various pages in the State Web Template (for example, header, footers, navigation, etc.).

Download and setup

  1. Clone or download the State Web Template from GitHub
    p>To clone the State Web Template go to our GitHub repository to copy template's repository URL.


    Or download latest State Web Template release ZIP file directly from GitHub releases page.
  2. Set up your page

    You can use State Template existing web pages to start. However, if your website doesn't use NPM or eleventy site generator use clean starter template code below.

    Clean HTML template source code

    <!doctype html>
  <html lang="en">
    <head>
      <!-- Required meta tags -->
      <meta charset="utf-8">
      <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1, shrink-to-fit=no">
  
      <!-- State Template CSS -->
      <link rel="stylesheet" href="/css/cagov.core.css">
      <link rel="stylesheet" href="/css/colorscheme-oceanside.css">
  
      <title>California State Webpage</title>
  
    </head>
    <body>
      <h1>California State Webpage</h1>
  
      <!-- State Template JavaScript -->
      <script src="/js/cagov.core.js" ></script>
    </body>
  </html>

    HTML page that is using nunjucks includes

    <!doctype html>
        <html lang="en">
           <head>
              <meta charset="utf-8">
              <title>State Template</title>
              <meta name="Author" content="State of California" />
              <meta name="Description" content="State of California" />
              <meta name="Keywords" content="California, government" />
              ❴% include "/src/_includes/head-css-js.njk" %❵
           </head>
           <body>
              <header role="banner" id="header" class="global-header fixed">
                 <div id="skip-to-content"><a href="#main-content">Skip to Main Content</a></div>
                 ❴% include "/src/_includes/utility-header.njk" %❵/span>
                 ❴% include "/src/_includes/settings-bar.njk" %❵
                 ❴% include "/src/_includes/site-header.njk" %❵
                 ❴% include "/src/_includes/mobile-controls.njk" %❵
                 <div class="navigation-search full-width-nav container">
                    <div id="head-search" class="search-container search-container featured-search">
                      ❴% include "/src/_includes/search.njk" %❵
                    </div>
                    ❴% include "/src/_includes/navigation.njk" %❵
                 </div>
              </header>
              <div id="main-content" class="main-content">
                 <div class="container">
                      <main class="main-primary">
          ❴{ content | safe }}
                      </main>
                 </div>
              </div>
              ❴% include "/src/_includes/global-footer.njk" %❵
              ❴% include "/src/_includes/scripts.njk" %❵
           </body>
        </html>
  3. Using CSS and JS

    CSS

    State Web Templagte core css files are generated from SASS files that can be found in /src/scss/ folder. Multiple SASS files are compiled during the build process into core output CSS files that are generated in /_site/css/ folder. A State Web Template webpage requires these two CSS files:

       <link rel="stylesheet" href="/css/cagov.core.css">
   <link rel="stylesheet" href="/css/colortheme-oceanside.css">

    If your website doesn't use a site generator you can simply copy-paste the stylesheet links into your <head> before all other stylesheets to load our CSS. please note that you can replace colortheme-oceanside.css with color theme file of your choice.

    JavaScript

    A State Web Template webpage requires cagov.core.js JavaScript file to function. That file is generated by rollup.js processor from multiple JavaScript files that can be found in /src/js/ folder. If your website doesn't use a site generator place the following near the end of your pages, right before the closing </body> tag.

    Use CDN for better performance

    Load your website faster by using State Web Template CDN. You will only need to update CSS and JavaScript CDN url links (no local CSS, JS and font files are needed).

    <link href="https://california.azureedge.net/cdt/statetemplate/6.0.8/css/cagov.core.css" rel="stylesheet">
 <link href="https://california.azureedge.net/cdt/statetemplate/6.0.8/css/colortheme-oceanside.css" rel="stylesheet">
    <script src="https://california.azureedge.net/cdt/statetemplate/6.0.8/js/cagov.core.js"></script>
  4. Using includes and page layout options

    Includes

    If you are using eleventy sie generator you can build your page by using the State Web Template includes. Several common components (such as page headers, footers, navigation, etc.) are already included in pages using njk includes.

    HTML Markup

    State Web Template structure code: 
       <!doctype html>
   <html lang="en">
      <head>
         <meta charset="utf-8">
         <title>State Template</title>
         <meta name="Author" content="State of California" />
         <meta name="Description" content="State of California" />
         <meta name="Keywords" content="California, government" />
         ❴% include "/src/_includes/head-css-js.njk" %❵
     </head>
     <body>
        <header role="banner" id="header" class="global-header fixed">
          <div id="skip-to-content"><a href="#main-content">Skip to Main Content</a></div>
          ❴% include "/src/_includes/utility-header.njk" %❵/span>
          ❴% include "/src/_includes/settings-bar.njk" %❵
          ❴% include "/src/_includes/site-header.njk" %❵
          ❴% include "/src/_includes/mobile-controls.njk" %❵
          <div class="navigation-search full-width-nav container">
            <div id="head-search" class="search-container search-container featured-search">
            ❴% include "/src/_includes/search.njk" %❵
            </div>
              ❴% include "/src/_includes/navigation.njk" %❵
           </div>
         </header>
         <div id="main-content" class="main-content">
             <div class="container">
                 <main class="main-primary">
                    Page content
                 </main>
            </div>
        </div>
        ❴% include "/src/_includes/global-footer.njk" %❵
        ❴% include "/src/_includes/scripts.njk" %❵
     </body>
   </html>

    Note: Path to the includes will be relative to the directory of your page.

    You can also add any other html or njk includes to your page like this:

    ❴% include "../../src/_includes/modules/header-primary-banner.html" %❵

    Note: Path to the module include will be relative to the directory of your page.

    Layouts

    State Web Template eleventy page generation codebase uses several layout page options:

    landing.njk (full width page)

    page.njk (standard page)

    navicons-landing.njk (full width that has main navigation with icons)

    navicons.njk (has main navigation with icons)

    search.njk (search results page)

    components.njk or patterns.njk (page with dynamic left side navigation)

    To use use one of those option you need to specify layout key in your front matter data at the beginnig of your page. 

    ---
title: Your page title
layout: page.njk
---

    Note: You can inspect page templates source code in /src/_includes/layouts/ folder or learn more about eleventy layouts on layouts page.

  5. Running State Web Template locally

    Install Node.js

    Make sure your local machine has Node installed. To see if Node is installed, open the Windows Command Prompt, Powershell or a similar command line tool, and type:

    node -v

    This should print the version number. Othervise you can download it from nodejs.org

    Using npm to start the website locally

    Once Node is installed, and once you are in your State Web Template local directory run following npm commands to build and run the website locally:

    npm install
    This command will install all the nessesary npm packages to your local website directory. 
    npm run build
    This command will build and generate website's pages, css and js files. 
    npm run start
    This command will run the website in your http://localhost:8080/ and watch for any updates you are making to webpages or scss and js files.

    Output

    All the web content is generated into /_site/ folder, which is website's final output folder.
